2.61.text:
When Britain went to war in 1914
its professional army

5.97.text:
of three quarters of a million men
was small by European standards

9.60.text:
and suffered huge casualties
in the early battles of the war.

14.63.text:
Over the next four years,
8 million men were conscripted

17.52.text:
or recruited into
the British armed forces;

20.45.text: almost half came from outside the UK.

23.45.text:
Without their service and sacrifice,
Britain would have lost the war.

27.84.text:
They came from across the Empire,
from the plains and the mountains,

31.04.text:
from tiny islands and vast continents,
serving on every front

35.09.text: from the Equator to the Arctic Circle.

37.79.text:
Wherever they came from,
they served the same cause

41.00.text: half a world away from home.

44.80.text:
And one in ten of them
never made it back.

59.72.text:
The disaster of Gallipoli in 1915
ended British hopes of

63.22.text:
a swift knock-out blow
against the Ottoman Empire.

66.25.text:
And a long slog through
Sinai and Palestine ensued.

70.45.text:
The British forces relied heavily on
Empire troops with soldiers coming from

74.15.text:
Australia, India, New Zealand, the West Indies,
Hong Kong and Singapore, Palestine and Arabia,

83.28.text:
Though the Ottomans were cleared from Sinai
by the beginning of 1916,

87.72.text:
the Allied drive north was halted
when two frontal attacks on Gaza failed.

93.01.text:
But in April 1917 the British General
Edmund Allenby took over.

98.49.text:
As a believer in mobile warfare,
he decided to encircle Gaza

102.16.text: rather than risk another failed assault.

105.55.text:
Unlike the Western Front, where mud, machine
guns

108.69.text: and barbed wire rendered cavalry useless,

111.56.text:
mounted British Indian and Anzac troops,
and the Arab Egyptian Labour Corps

115.33.text:
that supported them,
would be vital to Allenby’s plans.

120.17.text:
He ordered his troops to drive deep
into the desert and take Beersheba.

126.31.text:
An audacious cavalry charge
by the Australian Light Horse

131.62.text:
Beersheba fell and the
road to Jerusalem was open.

138.05.text:
Allenby, its conqueror,
dismounted and entered the city on foot

142.83.text:
to show he had come as a liberator
and not a conqueror.

147.93.text:
By the summer of 1918 the Ottoman Army
had been driven north through Palestine,

155.19.text: This was exactly what Allenby wanted.

157.31.text:
He set about planning a co-ordinated attack
with cavalry, infantry, artillery,

162.12.text:
armoured vehicles and aircraft, intending
to annihilate them in one fell swoop.

167.81.text:
With the Desert Mounted Corps
blocking off all escape routes,

170.87.text:
and Arab rebels mounting guerrilla raids
on the Ottoman lines of communication,

175.27.text:
British and Indian troops
launched an all-out assault.

177.39.text:
At the Battle of Sharon, the Ottoman lines
were broken and panic ensued.

182.73.text:
Within days Afulah, Beisan, Jenin, Nazareth
and Haifa had all fallen to the British.

190.34.text:
The Battle of Nablus was
an even bigger Ottoman disaster.

194.38.text:
Following their defeat, the retreating columns
were attacked by British and Australian aircraft

201.30.text:
The litter of dead bodies and equipment
stretched for 6 miles

204.27.text: down the Wadi el Fara road.

207.12.text:
On 22 September British forces
captured the Ottoman 53rd Division commander

212.57.text:
and secured the Jisr ed Damiye bridge
across the Jordan River.

216.85.text:
The last remnants of the Ottoman Fourth Army
attempted to retreat north.

220.38.text: They were bombed continuously by Allied aircraft

223.10.text:
and their escape route was blocked
by the Anzac Mounted Division.

228.20.text:
Fearing the vengeance of Arab irregulars,
who loathed the Ottomans for their

231.86.text:
brutal colonial rule,
the Ottoman Army surrendered.

235.08.text:
The campaign had lasted almost four years
and cost the Allies 550,000 casualties.

240.61.text:
In a battle lasting six days
the troops of Empire, Commonwealth and Dominions

250.21.text: The Middle East would be changed forever.
